headline: Scientists' warning after making disturbing discovery at the deepest point of the Mediterranean Sea - Science - LADbible
context: Scientists have issued a dark warning after making a disturbing discovery in the depths of the ocean.
An international team of researchers headed down to the deepest point of the Mediterranean Sea, known as the Calypso Deep, around 3.2 miles below the surface.

annotations.paragraph: As shared by the University of Barcelona, a whopping 167 objects were found at the bottom of the Calypso Deep, mainly made up of plastics, glass, metal and paper.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the discovery of marine litter at the Calypso Deep.

annotations.paragraph: Published in the Marine Pollution Bulletin, the findings make up one of the highest concentrations of marine litter ever detected at such great depths.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives context about the significance of the findings in terms of marine pollution.

annotations.paragraph: The scientists used the Limiting Factor, a high-tech manned submarine, to reach the bottom and to take images that prove litter can reach even the deepest and most remote points of the Mediterranean, making for a stark wake up call over the environment.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information on the method used for the discovery and its environmental implications.

annotations.paragraph: A 'litter hotspot' over the floor of the Calypso Deep (Marine Pollution Bulletin)
annotations.reason: This is a caption and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: According to the report, 148 of the items are marine debris while the rest is thought to be of human origin.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the nature of the discovery made by scientists.

annotations.paragraph: “We have also found evidence of the boats’ dumping of bags full of rubbish, as revealed by the pile-up of different types of waste followed by an almost rectilinear furrow,” said Miquel Canals, professor at the Department of Earth and Ocean Dynamics and director of the UB Chair on Sustainable Blue Economy.
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a direct quote from a relevant expert, providing insight into the findings.

annotations.paragraph: He then went on to warn: “Unfortunately, as far as the Mediterranean is concerned, it would not be wrong to say that ‘not a single inch of it is clean’.”
